title: Will the conviction of Adnan Syed, featured on the "Serial" podcast, be overturned before the end of 2016?

One hopes, therefore, that this delay is down to the holiday and not to crass ineptitude.  I should lose big on this one if they know what they're doing.  Stay tuned.

Know the power players: Baltimore/Maryland Prosecution and Police: Objective: Keep from overturning the conviction of Syed, and to protect themselves from legal issues relating to their method of handling the case in 1999; Power: High; their reputation is at stake and with such a highly public case, they want to keep from overturning the conviction at all costs; they also have high power in terms of connections, resources and more Syed and his defense: Objective: Overturn the conviction as soon as possible and bring light to the faults of the justice system, in this case especially; Power: Medium; Although Syed hasn't had success in past motions, with the overwhelming support of the public as a result of Serial, and emergence of significant new evidence to use to petition for a retrial, Syed and his defense have the most power now that they have had yet Public/Syed Supporters/Serial Podcast Listeners: Objective: Secure a fair trial for Syed, and bring light to the failings of the justice system in this case and otherwise; Power: Medium; The public doesn't have the same resources, from a legal or institutional perspective, as the prosecution, but they have acted essentially as thousands of investigators in the case; they have also brought the case a ton of publicity, particularly when it comes to the potential failings of the prosecution The power is fairly evenly distributed here between anti-Syed and pro-Syed parties, which means that although power of the players is worth keeping an eye on, it doesn’t affect the forecast significantly as of now. Norms, Rules and Protocols: The judge on the retrial hearing has yet to rule and also hasn't released a timeline for doing so.  If he rules no, then the question will resolve as a “no” already.   If he rules yes on the retrial, the process of preparing for and executing a trial that is so 1) public 2) heavily based on reanalyzing old evidence and 3) wrought with potential legal issues for the Baltimore Police Dept and beyond, will be long and arduous.  Average length of pre-trial motions, trial, and pre-sentencing procedures for felony cases is 4 months - 3 years; even if this case falls in the low-middle end of this range, the outcome of a trial wouldn’t happen until past the end of 2016. Select the right amount of effort per question:  This question isn’t even “in play” until the motion for retrial is granted, which isn’t even for sure yet.  It makes sense to only put a moderate amount of effort into the question right now, saving more rigorous analysis for the case in which the retrial is granted.

Once again, one finds oneself lacking confidence in the people who write the Qs here.  His conviction is overturned if he is granted a new trial, because that will mean his first one was invalid and the conviction is nullified.  He does not have to be declared Not Guilty for this to happen, and indeed he may be convicted again in the new trial.   I wish I were sure that the GJedi understood this; I worry that they think his conviction is not overturned unless he is found Not Guilty.  "New evidence" is not as such grounds for overturning a verdict, as appeals can only be taken on procedural defects at trial.  Actual innocence is not in itself grounds--do recall that the late Justice Scalia upheld the right of states to execute people whose innocence was not in doubt, as long as there were no defects in the trial that convicted them.  Nonetheless, he was great fun at parties.  In any case, overturning a verdict is fairly rare, and often time-consuming, so guesses on the low side are pretty safe.

To the extent that his team's argument depends on an appellate judge to understand or learn anything about technology, they are doomed. Most appellate judges are too old to figure out how to check their e-mail without deleting all the photos ever taken of their grandchildren, including those (the photos, not the grandchildren) residing quietly in a dresser drawer.

Working on remembering that the question is not whether he's guilty, or whether he'll be acquitted on retrial, but whether he'll get a new trial at all, since that's what happens when you overturn a conviction.  I still don't think so, but I have to concentrate on this distinction every goddam day.

There is some blowback against media-based exoneration since the egregious bias of "Making of a Murderer," but once an issue is back in the courts, this matters less.  The legal system (not in any way a "justice system") works slowly, spasmodically, and frequently erroneously, and tends to resist media pressure more than perhaps it should.  This person may get a new trial, but probably not very soon.  Still holding at a low p for him.

Between (a) nothing in the US legal system moves fast, and (b) there are lots of points at which the process could stop, just inching up a bit for now.

It is hard to overturn a case based on extrinsic evidence.  And that is what is required if the evidence submitted on the podcast is to be believed.  Plus, based on the podcast alone, I think he is guilty.

In searching for a base rate for this question, I wasn't able to find the data for how many murder convictions have been overturned in the US. I did come across the following links which make a case that the rate of death-row false convictions is about 4%:
http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/many-prisoners-on-death-row-are-wrongfully-convicted/
http://phenomena.nationalgeographic.com/2014/04/28/how-many-people-are-wrongly-convicted-researchers-do-the-math/ I think that 4% rate is as good as any to use as a base rate for false murder convictions, but how many of those who are falsely convicted are ever exonerated? It must be lower– much lower. I'm sure that half is too high, but for this purpose let's call it half, which means a base rate of 2%. There are a number of factors which I think reduce this rate in the Syed case. According to the Innocence Project (IP), the leading contributing factor (63%) for homicide case exonerations is false confession. This was not a factor in the Syed case.  IP lists other important factors as DNA evidence, eyewitness misidentification testimony, unvalidated or improper forensic science, and informants. The only one of these that could apply in this case is informant issues (with Jay being Jay) but this is not the basis for the appeal. In addition, successful appeals often have the support of the prosecution/police and that is not the case here. The prosecution strongly opposes, and the judge hearing the appeal is the same judge who denied the first post-conviction appeal. I think all of the above reduces the chances of exoneration to near zero.
Sources: http://www.innocenceproject.org/free-innocent/improve-the-law/fact-sheets/dna-exonerations-nationwide ; http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/bs-md-syed-state-response-20150923-story.html ; http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/shortcuts/2015/sep/06/serial-podcast-what-happened-adnan-syeds-case But there are some factors that increase the probability. For one, I listened to the Serial podcast and have read some of the court transcripts, and I think the initial case was thin and I'm surprised he was convicted to begin with. Also, the IP is involved in the case, which I think has a positive impact on the probability of success. Finally, the large amount of publicity in the case must have a positive impact. I think that given these factors, 0% is too low, but I think it would be a mistake to go any higher than 1% unless additional information comes to light.

I think there is a good chance the trial judge denies Syed's request to reopen the post-conviction proceedings.  The same judge who has already denied post-conviction relief is the one who will decide.  The State filed their response to Syed's request Wednesday so a decision should come relatively soon.  I am curious to see if the judge sets it for hearing or just denies it.  Either way, it seems unlikely Syed will succeed but I may increase my forecast if a hearing is set.

Intuitively, I did not feel ethos from Syed as he and Koenig talked through the jail house phone interviews. Koenig did place doubt in minds with the issues she brought up about Syed's attorney, the timing of the drive from school to murder site, and the library witness (imo, portrayed as somewhat unreliable).  He's been jailed for some time now, and no one that we know of, has uncovered evidence otherwise or ratted anyone else out for the crime. I also have to question why this wasn't addressed when Gutierrez was disbarred/resigned.

Not likely. There have been two trials. The victim's parents believe that he is guilty. There has not been enough evidence to convince jurors otherwise, despite the massive publicity surrounding the case.
I'll go with the crowd prediction, scaled slightly downwards.   Overturning a conviction of this type is a long process with a low probability of success.

Central to the Hae Min Lee murder case and Adnan Syed's conviction is the testimony of Jay Wilds. As a weed dealer who was already wary of the police, Wilds put himself at a disadvantage by disclosing his involvement in the ordeal. In his interview with Natasha Vargas-Cooper, he mentions not wanting others (friends, grandmother) to get into trouble due to his actions multiple times as a motive for past events: Q (Vargas-Cooper): In “Serial” you are depicted as a petty weed dealer. Is that why you didn’t initially cooperate with the police? It doesn’t seem like enough of a reason to not talk to the police.  A (Wilds): It wasn’t just like I was selling a nickel bag here and there. At the time, this was Maryland in the ’90s, the drug laws were extremely serious. I saw the ATF and DEA take down guys in my neighborhood for selling much less than I was at the time. And they were getting sentenced to three and five years. I also ran the operation out of my grandmother’s house and that also put my family at risk. I had a lot more on the line than just a few bags of weed. This discourse suggests an individual who is aware of their own accountability and motivated by intrinsic factors, which would support the impression of someone interested in revealing the truth.  Although it is not unusual for memory distortion to occur with certain details or events in witness recollection, the motivations to entirely, falsely remember their involvement in a murder are few.  https://theintercept.com/2014/12/29/exclusive-interview-jay-wilds-star-witness-adnan-syed-serial-case-pt-1/

Given the attention it is fairly likely this moves quickly - previous procedural steps have already been accelerated, and the family/Syed's supporters seem very optimistic that a new hearing will be granted. That an appeals court remanded elements of the case back to the trial court is significant. Latest: http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/shortcuts/2015/sep/06/serial-podcast-what-happened-adnan-syeds-case
The wheels of justice turn very slowly. Defense claims about missed witnesses and flawed evidence interpretation could give him a new trial, I'm just not sure how quickly it would move forward.
Unlikely the case will ever be heard.
Long, drawn our process. The Court hasn't even decided yet if they will hear the case.
The interest from the podcast has probably spurred a closer look at the case but absent more compelling evidence than was presented, it seems unlikely it will be overturned

No; the issue comes down to the eyewitness--and her account directly disputes Syed's account.  Even if she is allowed to testify, he will have to explain why he claimed to be at school and never said a word about seeing Asia McClain at the library.  I don't see her testimony being enough for the courts to overturn the conviction.
Without knowing much about this particular case, getting a conviction overturned seems to be a rare and slow process. With clogged courts, I don't think it will happen in this time frame.
waiting for conclusive evidence to support overturn

Legal details matter. Overturning a conviction is a big deal.  Not even Syed's team is talking about that.  "Syed's legal team wants the circuit court to carry out additional fact-finding on the issue of McClain's account, which it hasn't previously considered. "We get to go back into post-conviction, like we did three years ago, basically bring in Asia and the court can then decide if the attorney messed up by not bringing in the alibi witness," Syed's attorney and family friend Rabia Chaudry told CNN affiliate WBAL. The circuit court still has to decide whether to reopen the post-conviction proceedings." http://www.cnn.com/2015/05/19/living/adnan-syed-serial-appeal-case-feat/ So this has a long way to go...

I have zero knowledge of how courts have handled cellphone tower info on location in other cases, I hear the tech isn't always accurate, but this isn't the biggest thing in this case. The witness who fingered Adnan hasn't changed his story.  looks like a battle that could run out our clock.  http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/serial-subject-adnan-syed-granted-appeal-state-maryland/
